alternatives.transcript: it's Sonya live with dr. Sonya Friedman

hello and welcome to our Wednesday show a bit later are you harboring some pent-up hostility toward the opposite sex we'll have our very own Battle of the Sexes led by none other than outrageous funny man Jay Thomas now for a news maker it was during his tenure as Surgeon General that nicotine was labeled a drug and that secondhand smoke was dubbed a health risk from 1981 until he resigned last month C Everett Koop but a fervent battle against the dangers of cigarettes

being a battle he plans to continue through events like tomorrow's Great American smokeout it's the 13th time the American Cancer Society has sponsored the annual event the former Surgeon General co-chairs the smoke out with actor Larry Hagman we are so pleased to have you with us today dr. Koop it's a great honor and you have had a tremendous impact no doubt tell us a little bit about what it means in a practical sense when you compare the addictive qualities of

nicotine to heroin what does it mean for the average smoker that is watching us right now well it means that all of the things that go into addiction what happens in your brain what happens to your personality are exactly the same with nicotine with heroin with cocaine and when you withdraw those drugs from individuals who become dependent upon them the physiologic responses are exactly the same and one of the things that has impressed me most in the last eight years as I have mingled with

many reformed drug addicts is to hear them say this doc how is it I could kick cocaine how is it I could kick pot how is it I could kick heroin but I can't get rid of this weed so people who have been addicted to all of them stay nicotine is the hardest to quit why do you think that is I don't know but you know another aspect about addiction is that practically everybody who's on Hard drugs is also a smoker and so we think that nicotine is probably a gateway drug to the

the abuse of other drugs and that's why we're so anxious not to have young people start well it's interesting you bring up the issue of young people if you take a look at the marketing campaigns and I've seen some of the newer ads they actually are marketed towards young people and young women in particular as I know now how do you start to change that when the marketing is so focused well it's very difficult because the cigarette industry has its own advertising code and if they adhered to it they would not have those young models they would not

wait success sexually athletically and in business with smoking but they abrogate all of their own rules and do just the things that they shouldn't and it is not just here but abroad and if you'll notice it isn't just that they're girls and that they're young but they frequently are black girls and that is the Target that we would most like to educate young black people those who are blue collar workers and minorities because that's where the pressure from the

advertising is going let's talk a little bit about the secondary smoke we've certainly noted that Airlines for example Northwestern particular has no smoking on their domestic flights what about sitting in an enclosed space or in a room and a work space and inhaling somebody else's smoke how dangerous is that really well it's hard to quantify it but in the year that I put out the surgeon general's report on passive smoking to other institutions the International Association for research on cancer

and our own Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences came up with independent studies have concluded the same thing and that is that other people's tobacco smoke or environmental tobacco smoke or passive smoking whatever you call it is detrimental to the health of the nonsmoker one of the diseases you get is cancer and in the most recent figures published by the Environmental Protection Agency they say that probably 30,000 Americans die each year from passive smoking and

5,000 of those died from cancer dr. Cooper's I was listening to speaking and referring back to your comments about females and particularly black females or basically any females frankly the thought of a smoking young mother with a child has the passive smoke being blown into those young lungs on a regular basis is something that we should probably note well it starts even earlier than that this morning I went to the Columbia hospital and we passed out little tiny t-shirts that

I'm a born nonsmoker because the smoking of a mother is transmitted to the baby and it does several things first of all when you smoke you inhale a lot of carbon monoxide from the tobacco and carbon monoxide has a better affinity for hemoglobin then does oxygen so that if you're a smoker a lot of the space taken up by oxygen in other people is taken up by carbon monoxide and smokers secondly if you're pregnant and smoke the

Terry that goes from the placenta to the baby constricts so two things happen to the developing baby when the mother smokes one the blood that gets there isn't as good as the blood could be without smoking but it doesn't get there as readily because the artery contracts so it is very dangerous for pregnant women to smoke beyond that after their babies are born we can find developmental defects in children whose parents smoked for as long as six years after birth

so parents are love that children should not smoke while pregnant and they certainly shouldn't smoke afterward doctor Koop I'm a little bit concerned and disturbed about something your impact upon the issue of smoking has been enormous I mean it is really incredible how one man has brought all of this into such focus and yet I hear people ask me and I ask to what about the issue of alcohol we're finally talking about alcohol as a drug and yet it doesn't seem to get the kind of focus and attention

when we know that it is related to Crime not to fatal auto accidents why do you think that is well I tell you there are several reasons one is that we've been through prohibition and if we hadn't been through prohibition I think you'd find the same kind of reaction to alcohol that there was before say 1914 but there is there are two things to remember tobacco is bad for anybody who inhales the smoke but alcohol is not bad except for those people who abuse it and about 15

18% of Americans do abuse alcohol let me tell you the figures in reference to Deaths because they're very impressive the number of people who died in the United States last year from cocaine and heroin was about 2,000 if they were also alcoholics and on those drugs the number was 10,000 the number of people who died from alcohol was 50,000 25,000 of those died from the diseases that alcohol produces such as cirrhosis of the liver
liver but 25,000 of them were killed in drunk-driving accidents now that's 2,000 10,000 50,000 smoking kills 390,000 year that's more than 1000 funerals a day

well that's a very interesting comparison of Statistics I thank you for that by the way getting back to smoking for just a moment I understand that Greensboro North Carolina is going to be a smoke-free City do you see that as a trend in the future I see it as a remarkable happening because that is the home base of one of the three major tobacco cigarette manufacturers in this country it isn't going to be a smoke-free City but they have re have enacted restrictive ordinances for smoking in public places having segregated restaurants and so forth

what but I think the message is this if you can happen in Greensboro North Carolina can happen anywhere we're going to have an opportunity to have you stay with us give our viewers a chance to speak with you and continue our discussion if you'd like to join us in speak with dr. Koop 2 1 3 4 6 9 5 5 3 3 is our number

we're talking with former Surgeon General G is C Everett Koop about the dangers of tobacco will go to our phones right now actually we're going to be talking about much more than just tobacco dr. Cooper let's begin here with Claude and California hello Chloe Sonia yes and thank you for a great show Doctor I like to know if you heard of sugar Blues by William Duffy and also about getting a movement together for taking alcohol and cigarettes out a grocery store so kids won't see them in such a young age

I don't know about the book you mentioned I think that it's going to be very difficult to ever get any legislation that removed alcohol and tobacco from where youngsters could see it I think you can get soft porn magazines off the shelves where they can go through them but I don't think the American people would like to what they would consider to be an impingement on their freedom to do that that's got a text and say hello to Jim

yeah my question is is you know somehow I've always wondered why Alcohol Tobacco and Firearms are put into the same some same Department as if Alcohol Tobacco have the same constitutional right as people bearing arm I don't know the beginnings of that but I think it was probably because of the taxation in the beginning rather than any other aspect of it
let's move on to Donald in Texas

hello Donald hello dr. Cooper I wondered if you could comment on the pros and cons of the legalization of drugs especially following the lead articles that recently appeared in science by an associate professor from MIT favoring the legalization of drugs or at least starting a discussion on that issue thank you very well for discussion on the legalization of drugs and going on for a long time and when one sees the crime associated with hard drugs

because of the high street price of those products it's tempting to think a little bit about how it might be if you could go out and procure these drugs without any difficulty we have two drugs right now on the market that are legal one is alcohol I just told you it kills 50,000 people a year and the other is tobacco and that kills three hundred ninety thousand people a year because they're both legal and their use is unrestricted cigarettes and

arrestingly enough the only product In America which when taken as advertised will kill you now let's talk about something like cocaine I'd like to approach it from where I come from I've worked with children all my life I think I know a good deal about teenagers they're marvelous people but they have several faults one is that they think they're Immortal the other is that they like to take risks the third thing is that they never think a health message is for them and finally any admonition that begins with the word

don't is for somebody else I think that if you were to make cocaine especially when you can change cocaine into crack make that available to the teenagers of America you would risk losing one generation of American kids I don't think it's worth it talking about losing Generations I'd like to ask you about your message concerning safe sex and condoms and and how you feel that's come across and if there's more that needs to be done in that area well I never have used the

word safe sex I sometimes I've used the word safer sex and my messages about AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases have always been along those lines of the same litany the only absolutely certain way to be sure that you're not going to pick up one of the organisms that produces a venereal disease or the HIV is abstinence that is not for many people a viable alternative all there was a very wise thing for young

able to postpone their sex lives for a few years this country exists primarily on mutually faithful monogamy that's the way most Americans live now as a health officer when I was Surgeon General I used to say if you don't listen to either one of those two messages and you persist in a lifestyle that exposes you to risk then you have to take some precautions and the only precautions we have to offer you our the use of a condom so that always put it third

and said a condom is not 100% safe but certainly safer than nothing at all it's interesting you know when you first came to office I think a lot of people felt that you get to take a extremely conservative view I know that that is your personal view yet you can serve it of you see conservative means the conservation of life and that's what I'm trying to serve okay you've answered that and I thank you for that will go on to Paul and Washington d.c. hello Paula hello I respect and greatly appreciate the surgeons for my surgery

I can't talk summer surgeon general's leadership and appreciate the fact that his Integrity has been so outstanding on so many issues and would ask one quick question concerning marijuana smoke in terms of how it Compares with the lung damage of cigarette smoke

we don't have all the information in yet I can tell you that I said in a press conference in Miami in 1984 that when all of the information was in on marijuana when we had 25 years experience of heavy smokers with marijuana we would find that it probably was just as bad or perhaps worse than tobacco now I can tell you that there are some early preliminary studies that are being reported right now not about the occasional pot smoker not about the kid who smokes at 42 years

gives it up but people who have been smoking it steadily for the last eight to ten years they are turning up with very serious problems with new and unusual cancers of the nose throat mouth and also lung cancer so don't assume that because you don't know a lot of the health aspects and the consequences of smoking pot that it is safe

that's a group of you were in your formal position now if you still maintain that at certain general what would be the lead issue for you today well it's still the the issues haven't changed since I left office which is just a matter of a few months now smoking is and will be I'm afraid for many years the number one public health problem America a because so many people died from it and that of course means additional disease and disability but also

it is an addictive drug and so hard to give up even though you understand the health hazards you know 95% of high school kids who smoke say that they would like to quit and that they know that they will not be smoking in six years but when you study them eight years later you find that 40% of are still smoking interesting we're going to have you stay with us and we'll be back with more with our former Surgeon General right after this

tomorrow the American Cancer Society is sponsoring its 13th annual Great American smokeout um we are talking with former Surgeon General C Everett Koop will continue with our phones and say hello to Bob and California hello Bob how you doing it's an honor doctor Koop I like to just ask I got three young daughters and I am a black American and my neighborhood is

saturated with cracked and we have liquor stores on every other Corner in a black area now you say that a lot of the commercial ads are aimed towards young black women what am I what am I as a black concern father post you know think about all this well let me tell you sir I can tell you are a concerned father you tell me you're black I think that that's great and if you are a concern for that you don't have to worry about all those things because if you're concerned enough

you can overcome any kind of stuff that your kids are fed by the media by what they see on billboards and what they get from their friends just never lose that contact let me tell you that I worked for many many years as the surgeon in Chief of the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia and for 20 of those years we were right in the midst of the black ghetto and although things are bad today they have never been good in that kind of a community and I saw countless fathers and mothers

is like you who raise their kids properly turned them out well and they had the same kind of problems that you face but you keep on top of it you keep open communication you talk to your kids you tell them what to expect you tell them why that's wrong and tell them why that's not your family's way to go good luck

I think that Bob call was a wonderful call dr. Koop I would like to speak to an issue that's a part of what he's talking about we are seeing an explosion of drug-addicted children we're seeing an explosion of age children in this country what kind of a message has to go out to young women now who will bear the responsibility and the community at large also bearing the responsibility for what is occurring before during and after pregnancy with these youngsters well it is pretty

Hap's to one of the most difficult problems from the point of view of Education that we face in America if you think of the things that pregnant women do inadvertently unwillingly unconsciously to their unborn babies it really is tremendous tobacco is bad for them and I've already covered that alcohol produces the fetal alcohol syndrome and that produces neurologic defects that lasts throughout the person's life make them

unemployable make them a victim of society then we have the problems of cocaine and especially crack and now there's a new problem and that is as some pregnant teenagers near term they know that cocaine will produce contractions of the uterus will start labor and will shorten the duration of Labor and they say to their friends I'm going to smoke some crack because I want to have this baby in a hurry and don't

to hurt me well when you have a precipitous delivery like that of uterine contractions working against a closed cervix there is a great opportunity in an under normal weight baby for brain hemorrhages so we are seeing in addition to all the drug addicted babies born a whole batch in some of the cities of youngsters being born addicted to cocaine but also having had intracranial bleeds so that they end up with neurologic

seems on our spastic children the difficulty to answer your question I'm sorry to gun so far off the track but the difficulty is to reach people in time I ran for the government for five years a program called Healthy Mothers Healthy Babies it was a great Program in those we reached benefited by it it only had six points but the first of them was see your doctor early and often when you're pregnant well if you can't get them to see the doctor early then you can't get them to see them often and if you

get them to see him early and often you can't tell them the other things they have to know so to find where girls are when they're pregnant I think means that you've got to take clinics for prenatal care and parenting right into the high schools where they are and if you could combine parenting and all the needs for positive and negative influences there and prenatal care with the same time that you're giving Health messages about the dangers of Alcohol Tobacco and

drugs I think we might be able to stop it but right you know there's a there's a buzz word that gets in the way here and that is school-based clinics whenever you have a clinic in a school somebody says I will not have school-based clinics in my community because they think those are clinics which are passing out contraceptives to children and encouraging them to have abortion it doesn't have to be that way but I don't think you can reach him any other way okay thank you let's try one last question this is from Eddie Missouri hello ad

hello yes I'd like to ask dr. Koop judging for your full-length pictures I'd say you were probably 15 to 25 pounds overweight doesn't your own obesity cut down your credibility and Advising people of other things you have one month to answer that question I stood before my doctor and he said to me chick you're not obese I don't feel that you can go by the way I look on television all I can say to you sir is if you look as well and feel as well when you're 73

me a call dr. Cooper want to thank you for being here today you are a wonderfully informative man you've done a great deal for this country and we'll be looking forward to more thank you thank you we'll be right back
